content.text: CSS Multiple Backgrounds
In this chapter you will learn how to add multiple background images to one element.
content.html: In this chapter you will learn how to add multiple background images to one element.

content.text: You will also learn about the following properties:
content.html: You will also learn about the following properties:

content.text: CSS Multiple Backgrounds
CSS allows you to add multiple background images for an element, through the background-image property.
content.html: CSS allows you to add multiple background images for an element, through the background-image property.

content.text: The different background images are separated by commas, and the images are stacked on top of each other, where the first image is closest to the viewer.
content.html: The different background images are separated by commas, and the images are stacked on top of each other, where the first image is closest to the viewer.

content.text: The following example has two background images, the first image is a flower (aligned to the bottom and right) and the second image is a paper background (aligned to the top-left corner):
content.html: The following example has two background images, the first image is a flower (aligned to the bottom and right) and the second image is a paper background (aligned to the top-left corner):

syntaxHighlighting.text: #example1 {  background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;}
background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;

content.code: #example1 {  background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;}

syntax_highlighting.text: #example1 {  background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;}
background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;

content.code_html:
#example1 {
  background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);
  background-position: right bottom, left top;
  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: #example1 {  background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;}
background-image: url(img_flwr.gif), url(paper.gif);  background-position: right bottom, left top;  background-repeat: no-repeat, repeat;

content.text: Multiple background images can be specified using either the individual background properties (as above) or the background shorthand property.
content.html: Multiple background images can be specified using either the individual background properties (as above) or the background shorthand property.

content.text: The following example uses the background shorthand property (same result as example above):
content.html: The following example uses the background shorthand property (same result as example above):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
#example1 {  background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;}

background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;

: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;

content.code:
#example1 {  background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
#example1 {  background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;}

background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;

: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;

content.code_html:
#example1 {
  background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
#example1 {  background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;}

background: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;

: url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom 
no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;

content.text: CSS Background Size
The CSS background-size property allows you to specify the size of background images.
content.html: The CSS background-size property allows you to specify the size of background images.

content.text: The size can be specified in lengths, percentages, or by using one of the two keywords: contain or cover.
content.html: The size can be specified in lengths, percentages, or by using one of the two keywords: contain or cover.

content.text: The following example resizes a background image to much smaller than the original image (using pixels):
content.html: The following example resizes a background image to much smaller than the original image (using pixels):

content.text: Lorem Ipsum Dolor
Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit, sed diam nonummy nibh euismod tincidunt ut laoreet dolore magna aliquam erat volutpat.
content.html: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetuer adipiscing elit, sed diam nonummy nibh euismod tincidunt ut laoreet dolore magna aliquam erat volutpat.

content.text: Ut wisi enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exerci tation ullamcorper suscipit lobortis nisl ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.
content.html: Ut wisi enim ad minim veniam, quis nostrud exerci tation ullamcorper suscipit lobortis nisl ut aliquip ex ea commodo consequat.

content.text: Here is the code:
content.html: Here is the code:

content.code_html:
#div1 {
  background: url(img_flower.jpg);
  background-size: 100px 80px;
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
}

content.text: The two other possible values for background-size are contain and cover .
content.html: The two other possible values for background-size are contain and cover.

content.text: The contain keyword scales the background image to be as large as possible (but both its width and its height must fit inside the content area). As such, depending on the proportions of the background image and the background positioning area, there may be some areas of the background which are not covered by the background image.
content.html: The contain keyword scales the background image to be as large as possible (but both its width and its height must fit inside the content area). As such, depending on the proportions of the background image and the background positioning area, there may be some areas of the background which are not covered by the background image.

content.text: The cover keyword scales the background image so that the content area is completely covered by the background image (both its width and height are equal to or exceed the content area). As such, some parts of the background image may not be visible in the background positioning area.
content.html: The cover keyword scales the background image so that the content area is completely covered by the background image (both its width and height are equal to or exceed the content area). As such, some parts of the background image may not be visible in the background positioning area.

content.text: The following example illustrates the use of contain and cover :
content.html: The following example illustrates the use of contain and cover:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
background: url(img_flower.jpg);
    
background-size: contain;  background-repeat: no-repeat;

syntax_highlighting.text:
background: url(img_flower.jpg);
    
background-size: contain;  background-repeat: no-repeat;

content.code_html:
#div1 {
  background: url(img_flower.jpg);
  background-size: contain;
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
}

#div2 {
  background: url(img_flower.jpg);
  background-size: cover;
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
background: url(img_flower.jpg);
    
background-size: contain;  background-repeat: no-repeat;

content.text: Define Sizes of Multiple Background Images
The background-size property also accepts multiple values for background size (using a comma-separated list), when working with multiple backgrounds.
content.html: The background-size property also accepts multiple values for background size (using a comma-separated list), when working with multiple backgrounds.

content.text: The following example has three background images specified, with different background-size value for each image:
content.html: The following example has three background images specified, with different background-size value for each image:

content.code_html:
#example1 {
  background: url(img_tree.gif) left top no-repeat, url(img_flwr.gif) right bottom no-repeat, url(paper.gif) left top repeat;
  background-size: 50px, 130px, auto;
}

content.text: Full Size Background Image
Now we want to have a background image on a website that covers the entire browser window at all times.
content.html: Now we want to have a background image on a website that covers the entire browser window at all times.

content.text: The requirements are as follows:
content.html: The requirements are as follows:

content.text: The following example shows how to do it; Use the <html> element (the <html> element is always at least the height of the browser window). Then set a fixed and centered background on it. Then adjust its size with the background-size property:
content.html: The following example shows how to do it; Use the <html> element (the <html> element is always at least the height of the browser window). Then set a fixed and centered background on it. Then adjust its size with the background-size property:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
html {  background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat 
center fixed;   background-size: cover;}

background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat 
center fixed;   background-size: cover;

content.code:
html {  background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat
center fixed;   background-size: cover;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
html {  background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat 
center fixed;   background-size: cover;}

background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat 
center fixed;   background-size: cover;

content.code_html:
html {
  background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat center fixed;
  background-size: cover;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
html {  background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat 
center fixed;   background-size: cover;}

background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat 
center fixed;   background-size: cover;

content.text: Hero Image
You could also use different background properties on a <div> to create a hero image (a large image with text), and place it where you want.
content.html: You could also use different background properties on a <div> to create a hero image (a large image with text), and place it where you want.

content.code_html:
.hero-image {
  background: url(img_man.jpg) no-repeat center;
  background-size: cover;
  height: 500px;
  position: relative;
}

content.text: CSS background-origin Property
The CSS background-origin property specifies where the background image is positioned.
content.html: The CSS background-origin property specifies where the background image is positioned.

content.text: The property takes three different values:
content.html: The property takes three different values:

content.text: The following example illustrates the background-origin property:
content.html: The following example illustrates the background-origin property:

content.code_html:
#example1 {
  border: 10px solid black;
  padding: 35px;
  background: url(img_flwr.gif);
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-origin: content-box;
}

content.text: CSS background-clip Property
The CSS background-clip property specifies the painting area of the background.
content.html: The CSS background-clip property specifies the painting area of the background.

content.text: The property takes three different values:
content.html: The property takes three different values:

content.text: The following example illustrates the background-clip property:
content.html: The following example illustrates the background-clip property:

content.code_html:
#example1 {
  border: 10px dotted black;
  padding: 35px;
  background: yellow;
  background-clip: content-box;
}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What property is used to apply multiple background images to a single element?
content.html: What property is used to apply multiple background images to a single element?

metadata.question: What property is used to apply multiple background images to a single element?

content.question: What property is used to apply multiple background images to a single element?

content.text: CSS Advanced Background Properties

content.code_html:
Property Description
background A shorthand property for setting all the background properties in one declaration
background-clip Specifies the painting area of the background
background-image Specifies one or more background images for an element
background-origin Specifies where the background image(s) is/are positioned
background-size Specifies the size of the background image(s)
